text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 4.71.10 provides guidance and information to assist agents in the identiﬁcation of unrelated business income (UBI) and gives procedures for examining and closing Form 990-T, Exempt Organization Business Income Tax Return, secured during the examination of a Form 5500

Renamed IRM 4.71.10.1 from Overview of Form 990-T Examinations to Program, Scope and Objectives. Enhanced the section and subsections thereunder, by adding more information on the internal controls regulating EP Examinations.
Removed references to obsoleted manual sections IRM 1.2.10 and IRM 1.2.13 in IRM section

Added new section IRM 4.71.10.1.4, Contact Information for Business Units, to reduce the need for multiple edits to this IRM when contact information changes. The new section also facilitates ﬁnding contact information.

Added the IRM sections listed below to incorporate the March 20, 2019 memorandum from the Commissioner, Tax-Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE) titled, Guidance for Cases Affected by Federally Declared Disaster, or Terrorist or Military Action. This memo provides guidance to employees working cases with taxpayers affected by a “federally declared disaster” (a federally declared disaster, or terroristic or military action) under IRC 7508A. Generally, contact with the taxpayer is suspended and outstanding deadlines are automatically extended to the end of the postponement period.

IRM 4.71.10.1.6, Cases Affected by a Federally Declared Disaster, or Terrorist or Military Action IRM 4.71.10.1.6.1, Mandatory Suspension of Examination Activities IRM 4.71.10.1.6.2, Statute of limitations Expiring During the Postponement Period

IRM 4.71.10 was revised throughout to incorporate the October 5, 2018 memorandum from the Acting Director, Employee Plans titled, Single Type of Examination. This memo eliminates the Office Correspondence Examination Program (OCEP) effective October 4, 2018. Instead, there will be a single type of examination that allows the agent and the group manager to determine, on a case by case basis, whether a visit to the taxpayer’s place of business is appropriate or if the examination

) Many qualiﬁed retirement trusts invest in commingled investments such as partnerships, joint ventures, pooled trusts, common trusts, real estate invest- ment trusts (REIT) or some other type of combined investment. This gives the plan sponsor an opportunity to diversify the trust assets. (
) These types of investments may or may not be subject to UBI depending on the facts and circumstances. (

) Partnerships. Trusts can invest as either limited partners or general partners. The income derived by the trust is deemed to be of the same character and from the same source as if the trust, rather than the partnership, is the original recipient of the income. Therefore, a trust’s share of any partnership income is treated by the trust as if it is carrying on the trade or business of the partner-
ship. The partnership income passes through the partnership to the trust. This applies to limited partnerships as well as general partnerships.

applies to limited partnerships as well as general partnerships. a. For example, assume the trust is a partner in a partnership that izes in REITs. The partnership’s business is to research and then buy shares of REITs. Therefore, the income to the trust derived from the in- vestment in the partnership is deemed to be income from an in a REIT. As noted below, a trust’s investment income from a REIT is not considered to be UBI. In this example, any income the trust from the partnership would not be UBI. b. A taxpayer may argue that an investment in a limited partnership is a passive investment and that any income would not be UBI since the has no active involvement in the management of the partnership. Rev. Rul.
explains that an investment by a trust in a limited carrying on an unrelated trade or business will result in UBI. c. Additional information on partnership investments can be found in Rev. Rul.
and
CFR

) Pooled Trusts. Although a pooled trust is exempt from taxation, it may be subject to UBI. The tax is imposed at the trust level and is not taxed again when the UBI is distributed to the participating trust. (
) Common Trusts. These are essentially the same as pooled trusts except common trusts must have a bank as the trustee. (
) Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs). Rev. Rul.
and
CFR

(e) provide that a trust’s investment in a REIT is essentially the same as an investment in stock of a corporation. Therefore, any distributions from the proﬁts or earnings from a REIT are deemed to be treated as dividends. Dividends are not treated as UBI to the trust. Therefore, income received by trust from a REIT is not considered to be UBI. (
) Another form of UBI is income derived from debt-ﬁnanced property. IRC
) deﬁnes debt-ﬁnanced property as any property held to produce income and on which there is acquisition indebtedness at any time during year. (

) Examples of exclusions from debt-ﬁnanced income: a. Debt-ﬁnanced income that has already been taxed as a regularly on unrelated trade or business is not UBI. This is to prevent double taxation to the trust. b. Debt-ﬁnanced income related to the use of an Exempt Loan made to ESOP is not UBI. Per IRC
)(A)(i), any income derived from property which is substantially related to the purpose of the trust’s exemption would not be debt-ﬁnanced income. Rev. Rul.

Pooled Trusts. Although a pooled trust is exempt from taxation, it may be subject to UBI. These are essentially the same as pooled trusts except common trusts must have a bank as the trustee. Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs). Rev. Rul.
and
CFR

(e) provide that a trust’s investment in a REIT is essentially the same as investment in stock of a corporation. Therefore, any distributions from the proﬁts or earnings from a REIT are deemed to be treated as dividends. Dividends are not treated as UBI to the trust. Therefore, income received trust from a REIT is not considered to be UBI.
